Award.AwardTitle: SPECTROPHOTOMETER AND PROFILER FOR TERC FIELD STATION AND LABORATORY, LAKE TAHOE
Award.AbstractNarration:
The UC Davis Tahoe Environmental Research Center (TERC) has acquired and maintained a 50-year record of long-term ecological change in one of the world's iconic lakes, Lake Tahoe. Located in the Sierra Nevada mountains of California and Nevada, this is an area that has experienced, and is predicted to continue experiencing, great impacts on account of land use change, introduced species change and climate change. The two equipment items, a spectrophotometer and a profiling water quality sensor package, allow for the continuation of this unbroken data record, permit the calibration of a new generation of optical sensors, and help in the analysis and understanding of the causes and the consequences of change. The spectrophotometer, uniquely capable of use in ultra-clear water typical of Sierra Nevada lakes, will provide a regional asset for the study of aquatic ecosystems in the arid west. The long-term, publicly accessible database that continues to be acquired and archived provides an irreplaceable resource for scientists, policy makers, and the general public. The use of the data in the development of exhibits and learning programs at TERC's two public education centers in the Tahoe basin ensures that investments in science are being used to both educate and inspire school children and the general public about science, ecosystem stewardship and our threatened freshwater resources. Details of the research, monitoring and educational programs are available at terc.ucdavis.edu.

The primary goal for the use of both items of equipment is to maintain and extend the long-term ecosystem record for Lake Tahoe by allowing for stable and accurate measurements to be taken with new instruments. Secondarily, the equipment can be used in a broad range of Sierra Nevada and other lakes in the region. The instruments are ideal for use in a broad range of clear, low concentration Sierra Nevada lakes. The long path-length spectrophotometer permits new areas of research to be explored through high accuracy Colored Dissolved Organic Matter (CDOM) calibrations from the spectral response of field samples. The profiling water quality sensor package (Seabird CTD) enables year-round profiling to be maintained in multiple lakes. The instruments will permit an expansion of research on CDOM and density stratification impacts in high mountain lakes. Current research is highlighting the role of CDOM both as an indicator of change and as a driver of change in aquatic ecosystems. CDOM data are urgently needed to calibrate models investigating the potential impacts of global change on ecosystem health in the next 100 years. For more information about TERC, visit the website at http://terc.ucdavis.edu/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lake Tahoe is a microcosm for the study of a fragile ecosystem exposed to multiple stressors, and the role of science in informing government on environmental restoration.  It is a primary example of understanding how to manage for environmental degradation at the delicate urban-wildlands interface. The UC Davis Tahoe Environmental Research Center (TERC) has worked to advance science in the Tahoe basin and globally. TERC has staff, affiliated faculty and students who are working at a watershed, regional and global scale on forest health, land use issues, hydrology (surface and groundwater), urban stormwater, informal science education and limnology. New overarching themes have emerged (e.g. climate change impacts, invasive species) as major agents of change and new approaches to data generation (for example, real time sensor networks and remote sensing) have been embraced. 

Two deficiencies were threatening the continuation and the veracity of TERC's long-term (60 year) ecological record. The first was the lack of a high resolution, low limit-of-detection laboratory spectrophotometer that provides accurate measurements of colored dissolved organic material (CDOM) in very clear waters. The second was the continued availability of a high resolution, water column profiler for conductivity-temperature-depth (CTD) and other variables (chlorophyll, PAR, DO, light transmission, CDOM etc.). This grant enabled both items of equipment to be purchased.

CDOM (colored dissolved organic material) is extremely low at Lake Tahoe and many other Sierra Nevada lakes, which makes it an extremely sensitive measure of environmental change. TERC researchers have in the past tried utilizing instruments maintained by other organizations to calibrate our instruments and to track CDOM during episodic events such as algal blooms and sewage spills, but the short path length instruments that others typically operate for mesotrophic and eutrophic waters, do not have the sensitivity needed for Lake Tahoe’s water. This lack of baseline laboratory instrumentation in the northern Sierra region was a major deficiency. With the purchase of a long path length instrument, we can now calibrate in-situ CDOM instruments and measure the CDOM in water samples from Lake Tahoe and other lakes in the Sierra.

The second deficiency was the lack of a conductivity-temperature-depth profiler (CTD). TERC has utilized a borrow instrument for 15 years, and this arrangement was ending. The use of high resolution, profiling CTDs have become a standard in oceanography and limnology in the last few decades. They provide accurate data on the details of the temperature stratification with relatively little time effort and with accuracy of several thousandths of a degree. With the addition of auxiliary sensors, such as PAR radiometers, transmissometers, chlorophyll-a fluorometers, DO sensors etc., it is possible to simultaneously measure a synchronous set of important biogeochemical variables.

Broader Impacts - The equipment benefits a broad range of the research conducted at Lake Tahoe and Sierra Nevada lakes by and on behalf of many scientists, students and government agencies. Many of the scientists and students that are trained at Lake Tahoe go on to apply what they have learned elsewhere. The spectrophotometer is the only one of its kind in the region suitable for oligotrophic waters, and is a regional asset. The CTD is critical for maintaining the long term ecological record for Lake Tahoe that is unique in the western US, and of immense value in assessing the impacts of climate change, land use change and invasive species impacts. 

The data collected by both instruments contributes directly to TERC’s STEM activities. The excellent informal science education center and programs at TERC provide a ready-made opportunity to disseminate the results of all the projects that benefit from these data to a wide and diverse audience. TERC organizes and hosts annual events and programs for K-12 and the general public (terc.ucdavis.edu). Over 16,000 people visit TERC each year, 6000 of who are 4th-6th graders who participate in curriculum-targeted, school field trips that use TERC-prepared activities in science. 3-D visualizations and other interactive displays that TERC has developed. These are directly the outcome of the research conducted at Lake Tahoe, and the veracity and consistency of the data are extremely important to maintain the excellence we have striven for. 

The spectrophotometer data will help ground truth data from our autonomous, nearshore network and from our autonomous optical system on the NASA/TERC buoy. These measurements are currently not being taken in any other lake in the world, and therefore we are pioneering new data collection strategies. A fundamental use of the data is for developing, calibrating and validating models, that can be applied with greater confidence worldwide to understand ecological challenges in lakes that have had limited opportunities for data collection.
